definitions: short period of running at maximum speed over a limited distance
brief period of intense activity or focused effort toward a goal
examples: The athlete completed the hundred-meter sprint in record time
She broke into a sprint to catch the departing bus
The team scheduled a two-week sprint to finish the project
During the final sprint, developers worked overtime to meet deadlines

definitions: athlete who specializes in running short distances at maximum speed
examples: The Olympic sprinter trained six hours daily for the competition
Jamaica produces some of the world's fastest sprinters

definitions: small supernatural being or fairy in folklore and mythology
lemon-lime flavored soft drink produced by the Coca-Cola Company
small two-dimensional image or animation in computer graphics
examples: Forest sprites danced among the moonlit trees in the fairy tale
The mischievous sprite played tricks on travelers passing through the woods
She ordered a Sprite instead of cola with her meal
The vending machine was out of Sprite but had other sodas
The game developer created animated sprites for each character
Moving sprites across the screen required efficient programming techniques

definitions: wheel with projecting teeth that engages with a chain or perforated material
examples: The bicycle's rear sprocket needed replacement after years of use
He adjusted the chain tension by moving the sprocket position

definitions: young shoot or bud emerging from a seed or plant
small green vegetable resembling a miniature cabbage
examples: Bean sprouts appeared three days after planting the seeds
The potato had developed several sprouts during storage
She roasted Brussels sprouts with olive oil and garlic
Children often dislike the bitter taste of sprouts

definitions: process of seeds beginning to grow and produce shoots
examples: Sprouting occurs when seeds receive adequate moisture and warmth
The sprouting of wheat seeds took five days in optimal conditions

definitions: coniferous tree with needle-like leaves and hanging cones
state of being neat, smart, or well-groomed in appearance
examples: The Norway spruce grows well in cold northern climates
They decorated a blue spruce for their outdoor Christmas display
After a spruce up, the old house looked brand new
He maintained a spruce appearance for the job interview

definitions: informal term for a potato used in cooking or agriculture
examples: He peeled five pounds of spuds for the family dinner
Irish farmers harvested their spuds before the frost arrived

definitions: metal device worn on a rider's heel to urge a horse forward
projection extending from a mountain ridge or other geographical feature
something that encourages or prompts action or development
examples: The cowboy's silver spurs jangled as he walked
She touched the horse lightly with her spurs to increase speed
The geological survey mapped every spur along the mountain range
They built a road along the spur connecting two valleys
Competition served as a spur to innovation in the industry
The economic crisis was the spur for major policy reforms

definitions: act of stimulating or encouraging someone to take action or make progress
examples: His spurring of the team led to increased productivity
The spurring effect of competition improved overall performance

definitions: sudden gush or stream of liquid ejected forcefully
short period of intense activity, effort, or speed
examples: A spurt of water shot from the broken pipe
Blood spurted from the wound before the bandage was applied
The runner put on a final spurt to win the race
Sales showed a spurt during the holiday shopping season

definitions: series of Soviet artificial satellites, especially the first launched in 1957
examples: Sputnik's launch marked the beginning of the space age
The beeping signal from Sputnik could be heard by radio operators worldwide

definitions: series of soft explosive or spitting sounds made irregularly
industrial process of depositing thin films by ejecting material from a target
examples: The sputtering of the old engine indicated mechanical problems
Rain created a sputtering sound against the hot metal roof
Sputtering technology is essential in semiconductor manufacturing
The sputtering chamber maintained a precise vacuum for coating

definitions: person employed to obtain secret information about another country or organization
act of secretly observing or gathering information
examples: The spy transmitted classified information using encrypted messages
Cold War spies operated under deep cover for years
Industrial spy operations targeted competitor trade secrets
His spy mission required months of careful preparation

definitions: practice of secretly gathering information about governments, organizations, or individuals
examples: Corporate spying has become increasingly sophisticated with technology
The spying scandal damaged diplomatic relations between the countries

definitions: person who directs or controls a network of spies and intelligence operations
examples: The spymaster coordinated agents across multiple countries
History's most famous spymasters operated during the Cold War

definitions: software that secretly gathers information about a computer user without their knowledge
examples: The antivirus program detected spyware attempting to steal passwords
Spyware can track browsing habits and personal information

definitions: small group of people organized for a specific purpose or task
group of players forming a team in sports
examples: The police squad arrived within minutes of the emergency call
A demolition squad carefully removed the old building
The football squad trained twice daily before the championship
Coach selected his starting squad from thirty players

definitions: operational unit in an air force consisting of multiple aircraft
group of warships operating together under the same command
examples: The fighter squadron conducted reconnaissance missions over enemy territory
Each squadron consisted of twelve aircraft and support personnel
The naval squadron patrolled international waters for six months
Three destroyers formed the core of the squadron

definitions: sudden violent gust of wind often accompanied by rain or snow
loud harsh cry or scream, especially from a baby
examples: The sailing boat struggled through the unexpected squall
Snow squalls reduced visibility on the mountain road
The baby's squall woke everyone in the house
Her squall of protest could be heard throughout the store

definitions: state of being extremely dirty, poor, and unpleasant due to neglect
examples: Refugees lived in squalor in the overcrowded camps
The abandoned building had deteriorated into complete squalor

definitions: plane figure with four equal straight sides and four right angles
open area in a town surrounded by buildings for public gatherings
unit of area measurement equal to a square with sides of specified length
examples: She drew a perfect square using a ruler and protractor
The floor tiles were arranged in alternating black and white squares
Protesters gathered in the town square to voice their concerns
The Christmas market filled the entire square with festive stalls
The apartment measured eight hundred square feet in total
Each square meter of solar panel generates significant electricity

definitions: edible gourd fruit that grows on vines and is eaten as a vegetable
indoor racquet sport played by two or four players in a walled court
concentrated fruit juice mixed with water to make a beverage
examples: She roasted butternut squash with herbs for dinner
Summer squash grows quickly in warm weather
They played squash twice a week at the sports club
Squash requires quick reflexes and excellent fitness
The children drank orange squash at the birthday party
He diluted the lemon squash with cold water

definitions: exercise position where one bends the knees while keeping the back straight
act of illegally occupying an abandoned or unoccupied building
examples: She performed fifty squats as part of her workout routine
Proper squat form prevents knee and back injuries
The squat in the abandoned warehouse lasted three months
Police evicted protesters from their squat in the empty office building

definitions: person who unlawfully occupies uninhabited building or unused land
examples: Squatters had lived in the derelict factory for over a year
The landowner sought legal action to remove the squatters

definitions: practice of unlawfully occupying an abandoned or unoccupied space
action of crouching with knees bent and heels close to thighs
examples: Squatting in abandoned buildings became common during the housing crisis
The law regarding squatting varies significantly between countries
Squatting by the campfire, he warmed his hands
Traditional squatting toilets are common in many Asian countries

definitions: loud harsh cry made by a bird or similar sharp sound
loud complaint or protest about something
examples: The parrot's squawk startled everyone in the pet store
Seagulls squawked loudly while fighting over food scraps
His squawk about the new policy fell on deaf ears
Customer squawks increased after the price changes

definitions: short high-pitched sound made by friction or pressure
barely successful attempt or narrow margin of success
examples: The door's squeak needed oiling to stop the annoying sound
Mice made tiny squeaks behind the kitchen wall
Their squeak past the defending champions surprised everyone
It was a squeak, but they managed to pass the exam

definitions: act of firmly pressing something from opposite sides
situation where pressure or constraints make things difficult
examples: A gentle squeeze of the lemon added flavor to the dish
The squeeze of his hand conveyed silent support
The financial squeeze forced many businesses to close
Middle-class families felt the squeeze of rising costs

definitions: action of applying pressure by pressing something firmly from opposite sides
examples: Squeezing oranges by hand yields the freshest juice
The squeezing pressure must be carefully controlled in manufacturing

definitions: small firework that burns with a hissing sound before exploding
short piece of satirical writing or brief news item
examples: The squib fizzled out instead of exploding properly
Children enjoyed the colorful squibs during the celebration
The newspaper published a humorous squib about local politics
Her squib in the magazine criticized celebrity culture

definitions: marine cephalopod with elongated body, eight arms, and two tentacles
examples: The giant squid can grow to enormous sizes in deep ocean waters
Restaurants served fried squid rings as a popular appetizer

definitions: condition where eyes look in different directions
act of partly closing eyes to see more clearly
examples: The child's squint required corrective surgery to align the eyes
She developed a squint from years of poor vision
His squint in the bright sunlight made reading difficult
Through a squint, she could make out distant figures

definitions: country gentleman who owns land, especially in rural England
young nobleman acting as attendant to a knight before becoming one
examples: The local squire owned most of the farmland in the village
Victorian squires often served as local magistrates
The squire polished his knight's armor before battle
Young squires trained for years before earning knighthood

definitions: small bushy-tailed rodent that climbs trees and feeds on nuts
examples: Red squirrels are native to British woodlands
The squirrel buried acorns in preparation for winter

definitions: thin stream or small quantity of liquid ejected forcefully
informal term for a small or insignificant person, especially a child
examples: A squirt of lemon juice enhanced the seafood flavor
The water gun shot a powerful squirt across the yard
The little squirt tried to join the older kids' game
Don't listen to that squirt; he doesn't know anything

definitions: wound made by thrusting a pointed weapon or object
sudden sharp feeling or sensation, especially of pain
informal attempt to do something
examples: The stab wound required immediate medical attention
Police investigated the stab attack in the downtown area
She felt a stab of jealousy seeing them together
A sudden stab of pain shot through his chest
He took a stab at solving the complex equation
Let me have a stab at fixing the problem

definitions: process of making something stable or preventing it from changing or failing
examples: Economic stabilisation required coordinated government intervention
The stabilisation of the patient's condition took several hours

definitions: device or mechanism that keeps something steady or balanced
substance added to another substance to prevent unwanted change
examples: The ship's stabiliser reduced rolling in rough seas
Camera stabilisers help capture smooth video footage
Food stabilisers prevent ingredients from separating
The paint contains UV stabilisers to prevent fading

definitions: quality of being firmly established and not likely to change
ability to maintain balance or return to equilibrium after disturbance
examples: Political stability attracted foreign investment to the country
The medication helped improve her emotional stability
Engineers tested the bridge's stability under various load conditions
Core exercises improve stability and balance

definitions: process of making something stable or preventing it from changing or failing
examples: Market stabilization took months after the financial crisis
The stabilization program helped reduce inflation rates

definitions: device or mechanism that keeps something steady or balanced
substance added to another substance to prevent unwanted change
examples: The airplane's horizontal stabilizer maintains level flight
Bicycle training wheels act as stabilizers for young riders
This yogurt contains stabilizers to maintain consistency
Mood stabilizers help manage bipolar disorder symptoms

definitions: building where horses are kept and cared for
establishment that keeps horses for riding or racing
condition of being steady and not likely to change
examples: The stable housed twenty thoroughbred racing horses
She mucked out the stable every morning before school
The racing stable won three major competitions this year
He owned the most successful stable in Kentucky
Market conditions remained stable throughout the quarter
The patient's vital signs are stable after surgery

definitions: horse kept in the same stable as another
person or thing from the same organization or group
examples: The two stablemates often exercised together in the morning
His stablemate won the derby last year
The newspaper and magazine were stablemates under the same publisher
Her stablemate in the racing team offered training advice

definitions: accommodation and care provided for horses in stables
examples: The farm offers stabling for up to thirty horses
Monthly stabling fees include feed and basic care

definitions: neat pile of objects placed one on top of another
tall chimney or vertical pipe for smoke or exhaust gases
region of computer memory for storing temporary data
examples: She organized the stack of papers on her desk
The warehouse stored stacks of boxes reaching the ceiling
Factory stacks released steam into the morning air
The ship's smoke stack was painted bright red
The program's stack overflow caused the application to crash
Developers monitored stack memory usage during testing

definitions: machine that arranges items in neat piles or stacks
person whose job involves stacking items
examples: The automated stacker organized printed pages efficiently
Warehouse stackers can handle pallets weighing several tons
The shelf stacker worked overnight to restock the store
Experienced stackers could build stable pallet configurations quickly

definitions: large venue with tiers of seats for spectators at sports or other events
examples: The football stadium held sixty thousand cheering fans
They built a new stadium for the Olympic Games

definitions: group of people employed by an organization
long stick used as support when walking or as a weapon
set of five horizontal lines on which musical notes are written
examples: The hospital staff worked tirelessly during the emergency
Company staff received bonuses for exceptional performance
The wizard leaned on his wooden staff while climbing
Shepherds traditionally carried a staff to guide sheep
She wrote the melody on the treble staff
Piano music uses both treble and bass staff notation

definitions: member of staff in an organization, especially in politics or media
examples: Congressional staffers prepared briefing documents for the senator
The newspaper staffer worked on investigative reports
